Scout told me Twins were reportedly getting a lot teams asking about Povich. Was a sought-after player. FB avg velo at 92, tops 96 with curveball, slider and change. Scout likes his slider a lot, throws for strikes and chase. Called "polished, college lefty."

Yennier Cano is such an interesting addition. He‚Äôs not young (28), and he already appeared in the majors for the Twins. And he got lit up - hit around like woah, and walk rate through the roof. I wonder if Elias sees something in Cano like Voth. His numbers are so out of whack.

This was always the plant. You claim failed prospects other teams give up on (like Voth) and when they raise their value enough you extend or more likely trade them. It‚Äôs a cycle that likely won‚Äôt end just because the rebuild is about over. https://t.co/z6W8jHGzzY
Mike Elias was not expecting the Orioles to be above .500 and a few games out of a playoff spot on Aug. 2. He has not let these facts get in the way of his plans.

I get that Os fans are frustrated, I get it. The winning has been fun. Who‚Äôs to say they won‚Äôt keep winning? They‚Äôve traded pieces away and gotten more in return, this is what happens. Stocked farm system with guys on the horizon. It‚Äôll be okay, I promise. Love you say it back.

This is not about competing for a third wild card. It's about being a team that can compete for a world series on a regular basis. It can be done even in the big bad AL East. Tampa has proven that. Eyes on the prize #Birdland

For Cade Povich, 3rd round pick last year, lefty, only 22, with a SO/9 rate of 12.2. Don‚Äôt get caught up on ERAs, but he has some good ride on his fastball and can sit mid 90s with an assortment of pitches. That‚Äôs a good profile to build off of. He throws strikes, too.
Anyway, the business of baseball can be brutal at times.

It will be interesting to see how this plays out. In 2012, the Orioles were a fringe playoff contender and they flipped the switch, producing one dominant team and a fairly gutted out system. This time, they are maintaining integrity of their system to be sustainable.

If I had to put odds on who is traded I would say:

Mancini - 95%
Santander - 50%
Lopez/Tate - 30%
Another controllable bullpen part (Perez, Baker, etc) - 15%
Hays/Mullins - 1% (I think there is a small possibility if a surprise offer came along)

Ultimately, I think the Os will start moving significant prospects for MLB pieces this offseason (this deadline might be possible but given the cost of MLB players tends to be higher at the deadline I doubt they will), but for this season they need to look toward the future.
